aspect: 1. Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the hour record in cycling at the London's Olympic Velodrome in June.
2. Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, is expected to set a mark which will last for some time.
3. Wiggins will race in front of a sell-out crowd and his attempt will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.
4. Wiggins will look to beat the record of Rohan Dennis, who managed to cycle 52.491km in an hour.
explain: Sir Bradley Wiggins has announced his intention to attempt breaking the hour record in cycling at the London's Olympic Velodrome in June. This is a significant achievement and a core idea of the given aspect as it involves one of the greatest cyclists of all time attempting to set a new record in the most prestigious cycling event.

The aspect states that Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, is expected to set a record in cycling's hour record that will last for some time. This implies that Wiggins has the potential to break the current record, which has been held by various cyclists over the years, and set a new benchmark that may take some time for someone else to surpass. The aspect suggests that Wiggins' attempt to break the hour record is not just a one-time event, but an attempt to set a new standard that will take time and effort for others to beat.

The aspect states that cyclist Bradley Wiggins' attempt to break the hour record in June will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. This means that the event will be televised and made accessible to a wider audience, allowing more people to witness his record-breaking attempt.
The given aspect informs about the main aim of Bradley Wiggins to break the hour record of cycling by attempting to cover a distance of 52.491 km or more in an hour, which was set by Rohan Dennis.
